raw_text:
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
ALEXANDER CITY DIVISION
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE MCGREGOR )
)
PLAINTIFF )
)
v. ) CASE NO. DR-2023-900051.01
)
BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND )
)
DEFENDANT )
PLAINTIFF’S SUPPLEMENTAL RESPONSES TO DEFENDANT’S
CONSOLIDATED INTERROGATORIES AND REQUESTS FOR PRODUCTION
Comes now the Plaintiff/Father, Christopher Blaine McGregor, by and through his
attorney of record, Dianne James Davis, and submits the following Supplemental Responses to
Plaintiff’s Consolidated Interrogatories and Requests for Production:
INTERROGATORIES
1) Describe in detail each instance since February 27, 2024, in which you did not
allow the Petitioner/Mother, Brittany Michelle Gilliland, her scheduled visitation rights with the
minor children A.K. and B.M.
Response: Brittany does have her scheduled visitation with our son, B.M.
but our daughter, A.K., has not been ready to spend time with her mother, due to
Brittany’s own past and present actions. Additionally, according to the court transcript,
the Court stated as follows:
“All right. As y'all know, me and the attorneys have spoken
with the little girl, and for whatever reason, she feels the things
she does. You know, we're going to try to get to the bottom of it
and see what we can do to work through this and get relationships
better. You know, temporarily, we're going to go with lunches,
dinners, family, all of you together and try to get to where visitation
gets normalized.”
Brittany has failed to attend Court ordered family dinners, and on at least one
occasion, she chose to sit at another table and would not even speak to A.K., despite A.K.
asking her mother to sit at her table. Brittany has never approached A.K. during pick up
and drop off of B.M. for visitation. Brittany has failed to attend events and activities of
both children.
Further, the Court’s Order of November 6, 2024, regarding the hearing that took
place on July 31, 2024, stated as follows:
Following the in camera interview, counsel for both Parties, along with
the Court, agreed that proceeding with the show cause hearing was not
appropriate at this time.
Additionally, when we used to meet Brittany at the police station for visitation
exchanges, the police would talk to A.K. and would decide not to force her to go with her
mother. There was only one occasion in which the policewoman, Sheronda Cross, forced
A.K. to get in the car with her mother. There have been times when I have had to give
Brittany gas money during her visitation periods with B.M. and have had to DoorDash
food to her home because she had no food or money. I have consistently attempted to work
with Brittany. Brittany’s actions are a complete contradiction of her words in which she
has claimed that she wanted to spend time with A.K. and work on their relationship.
2) List all communications you have had with the children's school or educational
institution concerning Brittany Gilliland and provide the content of such communications.
Response: On February 19, 2025, I emailed Lisa Morgan (ATB/School Pickup
Coordinator) and provided the signed court order confirming joint legal custody of the
minor children with primary physical custody to me, and the requirement that pickup lists
cannot be altered without agreement. Email stated: “We can’t agree on adding individuals
to the pickup list for school or ATB so nothing is to be changed unless we agree”. Brittany
wanted to add Bradley Cleckler to the pick-up list.
On August 8th, 2025, when Brittany again attempted to pick up on days not
awarded by the April 14,2025 Temporary Order, I requested clarification from the Court
to ensure Brittany did not cause any scenes at the school. Once the Court provide the
Clarification Order on August 7th, 2025, I emailed the school with the clarification order
that was issued & calendars showing which parent had custody during that period so
administrators would have written confirmation directly from the. These calendars were
provided to avoid confusion and ensure the school only released the children in accordance
with the order.
On August 27th, 2025, I had a conversation with B.M.’s teacher about him
continuing to struggle in school with signs of ADHD. I forwarded Brittany the message &
information via text on the same day.
I have had many conversations with the children’s teachers throughout the years
and cannot recall the content of each conversation. However, they were all concerning the
children. Attached are email exchanges with the schools and/or teachers.
4) Please detail any reasons and the factual basis for why you prevented Brittany
Gilliland from picking up A.K. from school as stipulated in the Final Decree of Divorce.
Response: I never prevented Brittany Gilliland from picking up A.K. from
school.
7) Please state all facts that support your accusations made against Brittany Gilliland
of causing physical harm to A.K. or any of the minor children.
Response: Plaintiff/Respondent objects to this request as irrelevant and not
likely to lead to relevant information. Without waiving said objection, the
Plaintiff/Respondent states that all facts, testimony, including A.K.’s testimony, have
previously been presented and are part of the Court record. Plaintiff/Respondent has
viewed marks and/or bruises on A.K. and, when questioned, A.K. admitted that her mother
caused them and explained what happened. On one such occasion, Plaintiff/Respondent
viewed a mark on A.K. and, when questioned about it, A.K. stated that her mother was
spanking her with a belt and hit her with the belt buckle. Plaintiff/Respondent filed for
divorce the following day. On another occasion, Plaintiff/Respondent witnessed an incident
that occurred at Easter wherein the Defendant/Petitioner came to pick up the children.
When the Defendant/Petitioner attempted to hug A.K., A.K. tried to pull away but
Defendant/Petitioner dug her fingernails into A.K.’s arm. Plaintiff/Respondent filed a
police report and later, the school called DHR. A.K.’s teacher asked what happened to
A.K.’s arm & A.K. told her. DHR was called to the school, and they spoke with A.K., then
came to Plaintiff/Respondent’s residence and asked him what happened. A.K. has told me,
after confirming that her mother abused her, she used to lock her door at night to prevent
her mother from coming in. Her mother told her no one would believe her if she told them
her mother was abusing her. This broke my heart as a parent that I did not protect her
until the day I filed for divorce.
8) If you have conducted any surveillance, including but not limited to electronic
surveillance (electronic surveillance being defined as the interception of any voice
communication made by the Mother by electronically recording the same or by listening in on
any voice communication made by the Mother), of the Mother, or had any person or persons
conduct such surveillance on your behalf, then state what surveillance you have conducted,
including the date, time and place of such surveillance, the method employed for such
surveillance, the person conducting such surveillance, including the name and address of such
person, whether said surveillance was recorded, whether a written transcript or report have been
made of such surveillance, and the details of what was observed and/or the details of the
conversations that were intercepted or recorded, regardless of whether you intend to use such
documentation at trial. This includes anything related to rebuttal or impeachment.
Response: As previously stated, I have never conducted any surveillance on
Brittany.
10) Please provide a detailed list of the personal property items you have failed to
distribute to Brittany Gilliland per the Final Decree of Divorce, including but not limited to wall
décor, bedroom lamps, memory boxes, and clothing.
Response: Attached are photos but it was far too many items for me to list. As
previously stated, I gave Brittany all personal property she was supposed to have.
13) Please state the last-known date that A.K., a Minor Child, engaged in visitation
with Mother, pursuant to the original Divorce Decree. Please provide explanations for specific
instances where Mother was denied visitation, if there are such instances.
Response: As previously stated, the last known date that A.K. had court ordered
visitation with her mother was on May 12, 2024, for Mother’s Day. I met Brittany at the
ACPD to do custody exchange. Also, I and A.K. have attended the court ordered family
dinners whereas Brittany has failed to participate in several of the said family dinners. I
have never personally refused to allow AK to visit with her mother.
REQUESTS FOR PRODUCTION
1) Please provide documents or communications demonstrating the reasons for any
denial of visitation rights to Brittany Gilliland since February 27, 2024.
Response: As previously stated, Plaintiff has no such documents or
communications in which he personally denied Brittany her visitation rights. However,
attached are text messages wherein visitation was discussed. Additionally, attached are
charts and lists of activities, medical visits, and Sunday dinners in which Brittany did not
attend.
2) Please provide all correspondence, emails, texts, and written notes between you
and the children’s school or educational institutions regarding Brittany Gilliland.
Response: Plaintiff/Respondent objects to this request on the grounds that it fails
to designate a specific time-period. Without waiving said objection, attached are the text
messages, emails, and the like that the Plaintiff/Respondent could locate.
3) Please provide any recordings, videos, or other electronic evidence that
demonstrates interactions between you and the minor children wherein Brittany Gilliland was
discussed.
Response: Plaintiff/Respondent objects to this request on the grounds that it fails
to designate a specific time-period. Without waiving said objection, attached are
recordings and the like that Plaintiff/Respondent could locate.
5) Produce copies of all photos, videos, CDs or other evidence you have in this case,
even if you do not plan on using it at trial or any other proceeding of this action. This includes
any rebuttal and/or impeachment evidence.
Response: Please see attached.
7) Please provide any and all bank statements, passbooks, certificates of deposit, or
other written memoranda of any kind and description reflecting ownership by you in whole or in
part, legal or equitable, of any savings account or bank account or account in any financial
institution, including, but not limited to, savings and loan associations, credit unions, banks or
accounts maintained with any brokerage firm from the last three years.
Response: Plaintiff/Respondent objects to this request on the grounds that it
seeks discovery that is barred by the automatic stay under 11 U.S.C. §362(a).
Plaintiff/Respondent further objects to this request as not discoverable nor relevant
pursuant to the automatic stay. The Defendant/Petitioner is a creditor in
Plaintiff/Respondent’s Chapter 13 case by virtue of the equity obligation, and her counsel
already has access to all schedules, statements, and supporting financial documentation
through the Bankruptcy Court. Furthermore, since Defendant/Petitioner is a creditor in
the Chapter 13 case, she has full access to Plaintiff/Respondent’s financial records.
Submitted this the 29th day of September, 2025.
/s/Dianne James Davis
Dianne James Davis (DAV007)
Attorney for Plaintiff/Father
107 Main Street
Alexander City, AL 35010
(256) 392-3172
(256) 392-3578 (facsimile)
dianne@diannedavislaw.com
Certificate of Service
I hereby certify that I have served a copy of the foregoing upon the following via
electronic filing with the AlaCourt E-File System and/or by placing a copy of the same, properly
addressed and postage paid in the U.S. Mail on this the 29th day of September, 2025.
Barbara H. Agricola
127 South 8th Street
Opelika, AL 36801
/s/Dianne James Davis
Of Counsel
